text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

This transmits a revision to IRM 11.53.2, Communications & Liaison, Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE), Operations Support (OS), Communications and Stakeholder Outreach (CSO), Communications - Internal, External & Web Communications.
MATERIAL CHANGES
changes update organizational references, clarify guidance, and make the text easier to and use electronically.
follow and use electronically. This IRM contains the activities of the CSO Communications office and should be used in with other program/management documents. Added IRM

B/SE Standards and Guidelines
This material supersedes IRM 11.53.2, SB/SE Communications dated April 23,
Small Business/Self Employed Employees
Table of

The mission of SB/SE Communications is to help the SB/SE operating fulfill the strategic plan and the mission of the IRS. The role of SB/SE nications is to advance the division in meeting its business objectives expert communication planning, support for all SB/SE functions, and support and delivery of servicewide IRS initiatives. In consultation with the business owners, SB/SE Communications designs, develops and implements cation strategies and plans, and delivers communications for internal and external stakeholders. To accomplish the mission, the Director, Communications and staff will: a. Consult with SB/SE functions to develop and implement strategic nication plans that encompass ongoing and emerging issues. b. Provide communication planning and support to the SB/SE functions. c. Work with SB/SE business owners to enhance program understanding taxpayer compliance. d. Work with business owners to identify objectives and key messages with the appropriate communication products and methods to deliver SB/SE and IRS messages. e. Establish and maintain effective collaborative relationships with key internal stakeholders. f. Support outreach to the practitioner and small business communities by developing products for use by outreach personnel. g. Ensure appropriate communication relationships exist across SB/SE operating units and with other IRS business operating divisions and functions. h. Support servicewide realignment issues, as applicable. The Director, Communications reports to the Director, Communications and Stakeholder Outreach (CSO). The following managers report to the Director, Communications: (cid:
) Chief, Planning and Support Branch
(cid:
) Chief, Planning and Support Branch
(cid:
) Chief, Web Communications Branch Two branches have an embedded subgroup with a front-line manager: (cid:
) Product Development Group is in Planning and Support Branch
(cid:
) Visual Communications Group is in the Web Branch. The SB/SE Outreach Initiatives Database or OID (search Outreach Database on M

B/SE) contains a consolidated summary of current SB/SE outreach initiatives, delivery schedules and related products. SB/SE use the OID to retrieve information about SB/SE programs for external outreach. Servicewide initiatives that require SB/SE outreach delivery are included on the database. The database also features a section visible only SB/SE Communications staff for internal initiatives, communication plans, products, vehicle use, and other related information. Specialists are respon- sible for uploading communication plans and products for their respective programs and keeping the information current during delivery time frames. Products on the OID that are not for external distribution, such as talking points, should include an “internal reference” watermark.

) Each quarter SB/SE Communications develops an updated list of outreach orities and shares it with liaisons conducting education and outreach. A designated specialist requests updates through the team leads of each within SB/SE Communications. Other sources for suggested topics are Headquarters and Stakeholder Liaison Field and other IRS business divisions. Team leads review the OID views for which their branch or group responsible and, in consultation with the managers, work with specialist assigned OID views to determine which topics and views require updates, additions, or deletions from the priority listing. Topics for the priority list have at least one product (e.g. talking points, Powe
oint) in the OID view. the product in the view is not a Powe

) The SB/SE Communications director’s office supports all branches of Communications on a daily basis. The staff coordinates and follows up on Communications wide variety of controls and actions items and has numerous project Office bilities in addition to the following: (
) The Communications director’s office is responsible for coordination and clearance for the SB/SE commissioner’s messages to employees. Communications Messages (
) The communications specialists will work with their functional points of to identify successes/highlights/accomplishments for use in monthly for Executive messages. (

) By the first of each month, the communications specialist contacts the tional POC for a few sentences about a program success, highlight, group accomplishment, etc. (The POC ensures that it is approved by the director or designee; no further approval from the function will take place). (
) Within one week of being contacted, the POC provides success/highlight/ accomplishment to communications specialists. (
) Communication specialists will share input with writers’ cadre. (
) Writers’ cadre lead will share topics with SB/SE senior ops advisor who will determine which success the monthly message will address. (
) The Communications writers’ cadre will draft the monthly message with tance from communications specialists, as needed. (
) Messages are issued on the last Friday of each month. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) SB/SE Communications serves as SB/SE’s liaison with the Large Business and International Operating Division, which coordinates requests under the International Visitors Program (IVP). (

) The IVP provides foreign officials with opportunities to discuss tax tion matters with IRS officials and observe IRS operations. LB&I’s IVP uses specific guidelines for approving visits and briefings and generally through a network of contacts in IRS operating divisions, including SB/SE, facilitate these requests. The IVP office reviews each request to ensure it from a proper government taxing authority from that country. Generally, citizens are not approved for visits or briefings and are referred to other sources (e.g., a student studying in the U.S. working on an advanced or research paper on U.S. taxation policy). (
) All requests for SB/SE participation in the IVP should be directed to the munications project manager. (

) The communication planning process begins with the initial contact the specialist and a client, proceeds through consultation, and concludes development and implementation of a communication plan. (
) This section describes how to prepare and deliver a communication plan. (

) SB/SE Communications supports and helps deliver the IRS strategic plan creating and implementing communication plans to: a. Communicate the goals of the IRS and SB/SE. b. Provide internal and external audiences with accurate information to increase awareness, educate or change behavior. c. Influence voluntary compliance of tax laws. (
) Specialists in Communications fulfill specific program responsibilities listed the contacts directory on M
B/SE. (

) The communication specialist assigned to a client, program, or initiative gathers information through research and by conducting client interviews. specialist engages in an ongoing consulting relationship with the executive client or their staff to aid in accurately identifying business and objectives. (
) The specialist should use templates available on Shar
oint to guide the cussion during the initial contact and to draft an appropriate communication plan. (

) A strategic communication plan is a results-driven plan of action with a surable objective(s) communicating specific issues aligned with the strategy. Features include, but are not limited to: (cid:

) Target audience(s). (cid:
) Key messages for each audience. (cid:
) Communication strategy that will be employed. (cid:

) Not all assigned projects require strategic communication plans. For cation actions not requiring strategies, specialist may use a communication plan or a tactical plan, as appropriate. a. A communication plan is a plan of action to communicate a specific usually involving multiple tasks by multiple individuals occurring over a period of time. ) The plan is a working document subject to change; therefore, specialists should mark it as “DRAFT” until approved by the client and the Director, munications or his/her designee. (

) Plans require clearance, including: a. Technical review by client. b. Sign-off by Communications manager. c. Final review by client.The communication specialist will provide final, approved copies to the client, communication manager, project backup (Communications), and post the plan to the OID. (

) Communication plans are working documents, subject to change throughout their implementation. The communication specialist and business owner responsibility to develop the plan, and the communication specialist is sible for keeping it updated. (
) SB/SE communication specialists develop and maintain relationships with counterparts in other IRS functions (i.e., W&I, LB&I, TAS) and share tion, using appropriate channels. (

) When exchanging information with specialists outside SB/SE communication specialists must observe the chain of command and protocol for all divisions and functions. They should also use discretion in matters of policy to avoid requesting or disclosing sensitive or proprietary information. (

) Specialists assigned to a cross-functional project team that includes cators from other divisions or functions may discuss matters pertaining to project. Specialists should use discretion in discussing or exchanging tion that exceeds the project’s scope. When in doubt, the specialist should

exchanging information with specialists outside SB/SE Communications, specialists must observe the chain of command and protocol all divisions and functions. They should also use discretion in matters of to avoid requesting or disclosing sensitive or proprietary information.
consult with the manager, team leader or other designated contact who may elevate the issue to the Director, Communications or designated official in pertinent operating division or function. (
) This section does not apply to media contacts or queries. (

) SB/SE Communications strives to achieve clear, concise, and active cations. Writing style conforms to Associated Press standards. The Press (AP) Stylebook is the designated writing style guide, supplemented the IRS Communications Style Guide. Communication specialists also the guidelines of the Plain Writing Act of
Resources for writers are on M
B/SE. (

) SB/SE Communications produces several communication vehicles that internal and external audiences and has access to non-SB/SE Vehicles organizations’ vehicles. Communication specialists select the most vehicle(s) to distribute information and coordinate with non-SB/SE tors to reach audiences outside SB/SE. A chart with detailed information on communication vehicles is available on Shar

oint. a. Push communications alert readers to news, such as via email. Push is two-way, customized and sender accountable. Users receive tions without actively seeking them. b. Pull communications offer readers the opportunity to seek information through the intranet. Pull is one-way, mass and receiver accountable. the virtual world, pull communications include blogs, wikis, and Users elect if, when and how they will act on the messages in the pull model of communications. (

) SB/SE-owned communication tools and/or vehicles that reach internal audiences: a. SB/SE Connection is an online newsletter for SB/SE employees (pull). On a biweekly basis, a push email goes to all SB/SE employees them to the newsletter and the current articles (push). b. SB/SE Collection News, SB/SE Exam News, and SB/SE Specialty News are function-specific e-newsletters for those functions’ employees (push). c. SB/SE Headline News contains issues of interest to SB/SE Weekly highlights sent by email to SB/SE link to intranet content d. SB/SE Managers’ Messages contain issues of interest to SB/SE managers. Highlights sent by email to SB/SE managers link to intranet content (push). e. SB/SE Commissioner’s Messages contain topical monthly emails for SB/SE employees (push). These messages are linked on the M
B/SE home page under Executive Messages. f. SB/SE’s Business Unit News (BUN) is a link from IRWeb to content posted on M
B/SE of interest to all IRS employees (pull). The BUN is IRWeb in the “News from the Business Units” section. (

Small a. IRWeb Daily News (i.e. Webbies) - Headline items posted at the top IRWeb (pull) b. IRS Headlines - Weekly email to all IRS employees linking to intranet content (push) c. Leaders’ Alert - Weekly email to all IRS managers (push) d. What Do You Think?- Poll questions on IRWeb (pull) e. The Source - Newsletter for all IRS communicators (pull) (

) SB/SE owns several communication vehicles that reach external including: a. IRS e-News for Small Businesses, emails linking to content on for small business owners and self-employed individuals (push to sub- scribers; subscription option available on IRS.gov). b. IRS e-News for Payroll Professionals, emails linking to content on IRS.gov specifically affecting federal payroll tax returns (push to ers; subscription option available on IRS.gov). c. Stakeholder Headliners, e-articles posted on IRS.gov, cascaded elec- tronically by Stakeholder Liaison (SL) to stakeholders, and linked from e-News for Small Businesses or e-News for Tax Professionals (pull push). d. SSA/IRS Reporter, a quarterly newsletter posted on IRS.gov for employers, payroll professionals, and others who deal with payroll and employee issues (pull). e. Webinars, online training opportunities streamed live and/or recorded later viewing. f. Practitioner/Small Business Forums/Meetings, events hosted and locally by CSO Headquarters and Stakeholder Liaison Field to updates on SB/SE programs and policies to stakeholder organizations (pull). g. Congressional Update is a newsletter issued at least three times year that provides information on IRS programs and initiatives to sional members and staff. The newsletter is produced as a joint effort among Governmental Liaison, Taxpayer Advocate’s Office, Legislative Affairs, and SB/SE Communications (push). h. Video Portal houses video and audio files for external communications (pull; push when a video is linked from a Headliner or SB/SE page on IRS.gov). i. IRS Yo
ube channel, Small Business playlist (pull; push when a is linked from a Headliner or SB/SE page on IRS.gov). (

) IRS Communications and Liaison Office offers several communication that reach external audiences. SB/SE communication specialists should nate placement through the SB/SE communication specialist or branch who serves as the liaison with the C&L program owner for each of the following vehicles: a. IRS News Releases - Announcements dropped to the tax services and issued to the media by IRS Media Relations (push) b. IRS Fact Sheets - Topical information issued to the media by IRS Relations. Fact sheets are required for webinars (push) c. IRS Tax Tips - Issued by the media to the public by IRS Media (push) Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) The role of the SB/SE Planning and Support Branches is to develop and manage communications for SB/SE business owners and to collaborate with others in delivering key messages to internal and external audiences. Internal audiences may include all IRS employees and subsets such as SB/SE employees, SB/SE managers, etc. External audiences include the public and subsets such as tax professionals, small businesses, stakeholder groups, etc. (

The Planning and Support Branches are responsible for developing, finalizing, and distributing communications that reach targeted external audiences, including small businesses, industry groups, employers, and tax professionals, using specific communication vehicles. Products are distributed directly to the target audience and/or through SB/SE functions with stakeholder relationships, such as Stakeholder Liaison, Media Relations, and others.
11.53 Small Business/Self-Employed

) The Planning and Support Branches are responsible for developing, and distributing communications that reach targeted internal audiences. for Products are distributed directly to the target audience through SB/SE communication channels or distributed using appropriate non-SB/SE IRS munication channels. (
) The internal SB/SE channels include M
B/SE web pages, Connection letter, Headline News, Managers’ Messages, Morning News Break and products as needed. (

) Designated coordinators send story ideas, photographs, completed stories, their accompanying links as well as other submissions to the assigned communications specialist or designated co-specialist. Communications cialists determine the appropriate channel for disseminating the information. (

) The Planning and Support Branches (PSB) are responsible for coordinating with servicewide Communications and Liaison on communications that are HQ Media tionwide in scope and appropriate for distribution to the general public the news media. Communication products may include news releases, fact sheets, tax tips, and other vehicles owned by Headquarters Media (

) A PSB chief or an SB/SE communication specialist serves as liaison with Media Relations on all national news issues. All contacts between HQ and Relations and SB/SE employees, managers or executives will normally be ordinated through the designated PSB liaison. (

) Before developing communications for release to the news media, the communication specialist with program responsibility for the content must obtain confirmation from HQ Media Relations (through the PSB liaison) that subject matter is appropriate for news outlets and confirm the timing. The cialist should also allow at least a six-week window prior to the intended of issuance. This specialist may be from any SB/SE Communications depending on the program. (
) The communication specialist works with the program owner to obtain matter information. (
) Either Media Relations or the SB/SE communication specialist drafts the content to ensure proper format and clarity. (

) The specialist secures all appropriate reviews, which may include review for style by an SB/SE Communications branch chief or delegate and review for accuracy by subject matter experts, IRS Counsel and other technical reviewers. The program owner should provide final review and approval the understanding that the content remains subject to edits by Media Relations. (

) The PSB liaison forwards the product to Media Relations for finalizing and issuing the communication to the media. Media Relations may also with IRS Counsel and Treasury on final reviews and approvals. (

) When the IRS news release, fact sheet, or tax tip is issued electronically to media and posted to IRS.gov and the intranet, the specialist may with other PSB specialists and/or the Web Communications Branch on tional internal or external communications, including links from M
B/SE. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) A media inquiry is a request by the news media for information they may for a news story. Inquiries include requests for official comments, interviews, and fact checking. (
) Due to the sensitive nature of media inquiry, timely and accurate action is essential. (
) HQ Media Relations receives and responds to inquiries from national media such as: (cid:
) The Wall Street Journal (cid:
) New York Times (cid:
) Washington Post (cid:
) USA Today (cid:
) Nationally circulated magazines and the tax press (

) The IRS Headquarters Media Relations office coordinates media requests. HQ Media Relations office will contact the SB/SE CSO or Communications director or a PSB branch chief or liaison for assistance as appropriate with SB/SE related inquiries. (

) The PSB liaison contacts the specialist(s) assigned to the appropriate program(s) (i.e., Exam, Collection) requesting either answers to questions the name of a subject matter expert or executive to respond directly to the reporter. The Director, munications must approve responses to sensitive inquiries and requests for executive interviews. (

) Inquiries from local media and niche media, such as industry specific magazines, may be coordinated through the IRS Field Media Relations FMR specialists will contact the PSB liaison as appropriate with SB/SE inquiries. ) An SB/SE communication specialist in a PSB has primary responsibility as editor for e-News for Small Businesses and e-News for Payroll The editor will collect and edit articles, format the newsletters and prepare them for electronic distribution from the Go
elivery site. (

) Before release the editor: a. Confirms content, timing and any substantive changes to draft articles the specialist who has program responsibility for the subject matter. b. Sends the draft e-newsletters to the SB/SE Communications director for approval by the Chief, Communications and Liaison. c. Inputs and formats the newsletters in the Go
elivery system. d. Sends a test message to a designated reviewer. (
) Other SB/SE communication specialists will contribute articles containing content supporting their assigned programs, as appropriate, for these two e-newsletters. (

) The e-News editor also serves as SB/SE’s liaison for other IRS newsletters listed on the IRS.gov Subscription Services page. Specialist with content for those newsletters should contact the editor. (
) The directory listing SB/SE communication specialists’ program assignments on M
B/SE. The Subscription Services page is on IRS.gov (search under Subscription Services). (
) A Stakeholder Partners’ Headliner is an article providing news or updates important to IRS stakeholders. (

) Headliners are historical data which cannot be changed once issued, and be archived after one year. Therefore, the communication specialist assigned to the business owner’s program should determine whether the information should be incorporated into IRS.gov pages to make the guidance available a more permanent basis. (

) A Headliner should not be about the same topic as a news release unless ditional procedural details for tax professionals would be beneficial. In this case, the Headliner should reference the news release and provide the dural details not provided in the release. (

) Communication specialists generally propose topics for Stakeholder Headliner articles in response to requests surfaced through the Issue ment Resolution System or at a business owner’s request. Internal Revenue Manual

(04-15-2015) IRS e-News for Small Businesses and IRS e-News for Payroll Professionals

) The business owner should provide the communication specialist with a subject matter expert to provide background information, supporting tation, and review Headliner drafts. (

) The specialist completes the article and secures the business owner’s on the document clearance form (approval may be required from the executive, for example the Exam director or ACA Program Manager), then forwards the draft clearance form to the appropriate branch chief to sign initiate the approval process: Communications director, CSO director, OS director, SB/SE deputy commissioner and IRS C&L director. oint, and prepares a content publishing request to post the Headliner to IRS.gov, usually within three business days. (

B/SE. (

ganization events. The SB/SE commissioner’s staff creates their talking points for internal events. The designated communication specialist will take the following steps to create talking points:

ganization events. The SB/SE commissioner’s staff creates their talking for internal events. The designated communication specialist will take the following steps to create talking points: a. ) The Web Communications Branch Chief and staff are responsible for the SB/SE intranet, M

B/SE infrastructures and operating environments, the Video Portal and the SB/SE content portions of IRS.gov. The Visual cations Group within the Web Communications branch is responsible for SB/SE video production. (

) Submit all requests for SB/SE intranet sites to the Web Communications Branch Chief for consideration of appropriateness and business purpose. The Web Communications Branch Chief makes the final decision on all requests for SB/SE intranet sites. (
) All SB/SE intranet sites must fall under the SB/SE URL structure. (
) M
B/SE is the intranet site for the Small Business/Self-Employed Division. M
B/SE is a reader centric site that gives SB/SE employees easy access to tools and resources needed to meet job requirements. (

) IRS.gov is the IRS’s Internet website and is a major strategic tool that allows the Service more efficiency in fulfilling its mission to help taxpayers and meet their tax responsibilities. Use the content management application (CMA) for additional content uploads to IRS.gov. All requests for updates or additions to SB/SE content on IRS.gov should be submitted to the Web Com- munications team using the Content Publishing Request System (
) All requests for updates or additions to SB/SE intranet content on M
B/SE should be submitted to the Web Communications Branch team using the Request System. (

) This section of the Web Communications Branch IRM contains a collection of Web standards and guidelines. These standards establish rules and param- eters and provide guidance for everyone who develops and maintains content on M
B/SE. (
) The Web Communications Branch develops and maintains the M
B/SE structure and environment. In addition, the branch establishes and maintains policies and the Web Standards and Guidelines for publishing content. (

) The Visual Communications Group (VCG) manager reports to the Chief, Web Communications Branch. The SB/SE VCG is responsible for SB/SE video duction. The following is detailed guidance about video production, Yo
ube, webinars, and video posting. (

) The use of videos and webinars across the Service serve as important tools our efforts to reduce travel costs for training and face-to-face meetings. Our video and webinar efforts are a great resource as we produce a variety of internal and external communications that provide training and information for employees, taxpayers and practitioners. However, based on the current situation, the Service needs to evaluate all expenditures to ensure they are critical to advancing the Service’s mission. (cid:
) Video and webinar requests must be reviewed by the Servicewide Video Editorial Board (SVEB) and receive approval prior to starting production. See Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

(cid:

) In addition to the SVEB, the business unit head of office, a business unit executive and ultimately the Deputy Commissioner for Operations Support must review and approve video and webinar projects prior to starting produc- tion.(cid:

)Freelance video production is prohibited. Simply put: the only people autho- rized to make IRS video for any reason are those in the SB/SE Video Communications Group or the C&L Corporate Television Studio. If you have any questions, contact the VCG manager. (cid:
) Video covered by this policy include training and education videos, vignettes, videos for external placement on Yo
ube, IRS.gov and related sites, and any other ad hoc taping or photography projects done by either or contractors. Simple leadership messages to employees are exempt from needing SVEB approval. (
) An IRS Yo
ube video must be short, compelling, simple, helpful, and profes- sional. Good topics for Yo
ube video will have wide appeal among the general public. (cid:
) Yo
ube videos are shot at the IRS TV studio in New Carrollton. (cid:
) When considering a Yo
ube video topic, review the IRS Yo

ube channel make sure the topic has not already been covered. Also, VCG can do a quick check with Communications & Liaison to ensure the topic is acceptable. An online VCG project request form must be completed and approved. (cid:
) All Yo
ube scripts begin by saying “HERE’S A TIP FROM THE IRS. (one second pause) HI… I’M (FIRST NAME) AND I WORK FOR THE INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE.” Do not deviate from this. And most Yo
ube scripts end with, “FOR MORE INFORMATION. GO TO WWW.IRS.GOV.” The VCG manager can provide a template for Yo
ube scripts. (cid:

) In addition, text should be in all caps and double-spaced and each sentence must be its own paragraph. Each paragraph must be indented five spaces; commas are expressed as ellipses; acronyms are expressed in broadcast with hyphens separating the letters, i.e. (A-C-A or O-I-C). The title can be no more than
characters, including spaces; the tags can be no more than characters, including spaces -- in the tags section, take out the spaces after commas.(cid:
)Afterthe video is shot and edited, the Yo
ube client and C&L reviews it again before it is captioned and posted. Post-production takes two to three weeks. The IRS has its own Yo
ube channel. On the IRS Yo
ube channel a Small Business playlist where most SB/SE Yo
ube videos are posted. (

) TV producer - The person IRS Corporate TV assigns to coordinate the technical aspects of the production. (cid:

) The SB/SE Communications Division is responsible for supporting the dia needs of SB/SE functions. Support includes developing videos for and executive messages, other audio-visual needs, and webinars for that further SB/SE’s mission and goals. (
) Communications staff works with SB/SE functional staff to develop a script, and production schedule for each project. Most video projects require coordination with IRS Corporate Television. (

) There is a centralized fund for audio-visual production within CSO to pay for production of videos, webinars, and audio projects for all SB/SE (Webinar streaming is funded by a separate contract and webinar topics are subject to approval from the CSO Webinar Planning Team.) (

) Video projects require sufficient time to allow for planning, scripting, and post-production work. . Ideally, video and webinar projects should be included in the overall communication plan for each function to ensure adequate funding. VCG may have difficulty obtaining funding for a project is not in the overarching plan at the beginning of the fiscal year. Therefore, it important that clients meet with Communications staff early in the project to allow enough time for a quality production. Acceptable planning times range from about two months to five months, depending on the complexity of the project. (

) A fairly new video option is the use of Captivate software to produce tions with audio, video and slide content at little or no cost. Typical Captivate projects would demonstrate filling out a form or navigating a website. Customers interested in this option should contact the VCG manager for information. (
) The VCG is the liaison with Publishing Services for all CSO printing including outreach products. (
) Publishing Services manages the Service’s printing, design and publishing quirements. Publishing assists in the planning, producing, and procuring of print and media products used by the public. (

) A communication specialist whose client expresses a need for a printed product should contact the VCG to discuss the product, design services, estimates, due dates, and distribution patterns. Before taking any publishing action, the client must complete Form

to the assigned Visual Com- munications specialist for approval and signatures. Internal Revenue Manual

) The Content Board provides the division’s functions with a forum for inter- action and coordination for Web-related business.
